body_html:
@lucasdavid Thanks for chiming in. But if you want to continue the training you wouldn't run initialize_all_variables() either? :-)

I think TensorFlow should have three functions:

  • initialize_all_variables() that really took care of all variables.
  • initialize_global_variables() and initialize_local_variables() that did the more specific initializations.

If you are doing something clever/unusual that only require initialization of one kind of variable you are probably pretty skilled with TF and would know there are two different kind of variables.

body:
@lucasdavid Thanks for chiming in. But if you want to continue the training you wouldn't run `initialize_all_variables()` either?  :-)

I think TensorFlow should have three functions:
- `initialize_all_variables()` that really took care of _all_ variables.
- `initialize_global_variables()` and `initialize_local_variables()` that did the more specific initializations.

If you are doing something clever/unusual that only require initialization of one kind of variable you are probably pretty skilled with TF and would know there are two different kind of variables.
